ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was a twice weekly virtual seminar.
lots of online resources/readings
N/A

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about Russian literature and improved my Russian reading comprehension.
conversational russian skills, written russian skills, artistic/literary/political vocabulary

My Russian comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing abilities all improved in this course.

I also learned about interesting 20th-century Russian writers.

We read a significant amount of Russian literature at a level higher than that of the 4th year Russian sequence, and learned a good amount of Russian (particularly Soviet) history. We did not spend much time on grammar.

I learned a lot about Russian grammar and improved my reading, writing and speaking skills! I also got to study in depth certain works of Soviet literature and certain aspects of Soviet culture: I definitely was introduced to many concepts that were completely foreign to me!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoyed this course and felt like we discussed each piece of literature we read in good detail, but I felt like we could have covered a broader time period to see more of Russian history.

Prof Dolgova is an incredibly engaging professor so our conversations were fantastic. The one frustration is that it's never quite clear what we are meant to do for homework because Professor doesn't keep a detailed schedule

Strengths: Irina is a treasure, and she made the course a total joy. The literature was great as well, with pretty well-chosen readings. The course was also not too much work, and Irina have really fast and thorough feedback on every homework assignment. 

Weaknesses: The expectations on students were too low. I understand that Zoom made things difficult, and the level of the students was also likely lower than Irina is used to, but we had very few graded assignments and overall quite a low workload. I wish that we had kept the exams at least so that student engagement would have been higher. It was also often very unclear precisely what the homework was; some parts of it would be on Canvas and others would be described aloud, it would often be filed under the wrong date on Canvas. Often times we would have several readings, some optional and some not, and yet the professor would only ask about the optional ones.

Strength: Very small class, strong engagement with the professor and with the other students.
Strength: Professor Dolgova is extremely patient and will help you a lot with your language skills!
Strength: Exposure to a lot of background material that will really help you understand literary works.

Weakness: If any, the class could be a little more fast-paced.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class adapted really well to a virtual seminar because it's a small class, so you could see everyone on the screen at once and discuss like normal.

We used breakout rooms a lot which was great. In future online semesters, it would be useful to start break out room discussions earlier in the class time. We often ran overtime because we were talking in breakout rooms until 5 minutes before the end of the scheduled time.

The seminar was honestly not terribly affected, as I feel that students were still able to interact with the professor a lot and generally the conversation was good, even if perhaps it was too easy to get distracted. It was also quite helpful to have the sources and a dictionary in front of me while preparing to speak. The breakout rooms during the Zoom seminars were the biggest problem, though, as it was never completely clear what we had to do during them, and the conversation was often dead.
We received a lot of timely feedback from the instructor on our homework and our class was small enough that we could all participate in class! Overall, I felt very engaged during our seminars.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in getting a good introduction to Russian literature and to improve their reading comprehension.
Absolutely, any course with Prof Dolgova is worth taking
Yes! It's a great class and Irina Andreevna is a wonderful teacher.

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to any student that has taken Russian up to this level. Irina is great and this is when you really reap many of the rewards of having made it through 2-4 years of Russian, as the literature is great and the class is relatively chill. If you are considering skipping Fourth Year in order to take this course, though, I would hold back, since it doesn't spend a huge amount of time on grammar, and there is a lot you may miss out on.
Yes! Such a great opportunity to read interesting works, talk with super insightful people and really hone your Russian skills! The small class format cannot be beat!
